translation: ramię w ramię [used to say that two or more people are next to each other and moving in the same direction]
sentence: We were running two abreast around the track.

translation: graniczyć z, sąsiadować z [(of land or a building) to be next to something or to have one side touching the side of something]
sentence: Mexico abuts (on) some of the richest parts of the United States.

translation: przyjazny, uprzejmy [pleasant, friendly, and easy to talk to]
sentence: It’s hard not to like such an affable fellow.

translation: poprawiać, polepszać [formal; to make a bad or unpleasant situation better]
sentence: Foreign aid is badly needed to ameliorate the effects of the drought.

translation: zbić z tropu, skonfundować [to confuse someone completely; to be too difficult or strange for someone to understand or explain]
sentence: She was completely baffled by his strange behavior.

translation: z wyjątkiem, o ile nie zdarzy się [except if a particular thing happens]
sentence: We should arrive at ten o'clock, barring any unexpected delays.

translation: pluskwa [a very small insect that lives mainly in beds and feeds by sucking people's blood]
sentence: Bedbugs prefer exposed skin, preferably the face, neck and arms of a sleeping person.

translation: bezczelny [(disapproving) open and without shame, usually about something that people find shocking]
sentence: She had become brazen about the whole affair.

translation: siniak [a blue, brown, or purple mark that appears on the skin after someone has fallen, been hit, etc.]
sentence: His arms and back were covered in bruises.

translation: chrust [small branches that have broken off from trees and bushes]
sentence: These are the brushwood that set the forest alight.

translation: drgnąć, ruszyć się [(usually used in negative sentences) to move slightly; to make something or someone move slightly]
sentence: She pushed at the door, but it wouldn't budge.

translation: prezbiterium [the part of a church containing the altar, where the priests and choir sit]
sentence: These seats were usually close to the chancel, and sometimes within it.

translation: kronika [a written record of events in the order in which they happened]
sentence: Her latest novel is a chronicle of life in a small town in North Carolina.

translation: klika [(disapproving) a small group of people who spend their time together and do not welcome other people into that group]
sentence: There's a clique at work that never talks to anyone else.

translation: ściskać, trzymać kurczowo [to take or try to take hold of something tightly, usually in fear, worry, or pain]
sentence: Clutching the money to his chest, he hurried to the bank.

translation: współczuć, litować się [to show someone sympathy when they are upset or disappointed about something]
sentence: I began by commiserating with her over the defeat.

translation: przyznać, ustąpić [to admit, often unwillingly, that something is true; to allow someone to have something, even if you do not want to]
sentence: Even the company chairman concedes that the results are disappointing.

translation: dostawa, dostawa towaru [a quantity of goods that are sent or delivered somewhere]
sentence: The most recent consignment of cloth was faulty.

translation: pocieszać [to make someone who is sad or disappointed feel better by giving them comfort or sympathy]
sentence: He tried to console her, but she kept saying it was all her own fault.

translation: wykrzywiać, wyginać [to become twisted or make something twisted out of its natural or normal shape]
sentence: His face was contorted with pain.

translation: zastawa porcelanowa [UK; old-fashioned; cups, plates, bowls, etc., used to serve food and drink, especially made of china]
sentence: The store sells gift items such as crockery and soaps.

translation: tama, zapora [a wall built across a river that stops the river's flow and collects the water]
sentence: The Aswan High Dam is on the River Nile in Egypt.

translation: uznawać, uważać [formal; to consider or judge something in a particular way]
sentence: We will provide help whenever you deem it appropriate.

translation: oszukiwać, defraudować [to get money illegally from a person or an organization by tricking them]
sentence: All three men were charged with conspiracy to defraud.

translation: uznanie, gestia [the freedom or power to decide what should be done in a particular situation]
sentence: Troopers have discretion in deciding whom to stop for speeding.

translation: niezadowolony, zawiedziony [annoyed or disappointed because something has happened to upset you]
sentence: I left feeling disgruntled at the way I was treated.

translation: wyrzekać się, wypierać się [to make it known that you no longer have any connection with someone that you were closely connected with]
sentence: It's a story set in the last century about a girl whose parents disowned her when she married a foreigner.

translation: rozprawa, praca dyplomowa [a long piece of writing on a particular subject, especially one that is done in order to receive a degree at college or university]
sentence: This study was part of a doctoral dissertation.

translation: ulewa [a heavy fall of rain that often starts suddenly]
sentence: It is unforgivable that sewage works should overflow when there is a heavy downpour.

translation: nauszniki [a pair of small pieces of material like fur worn over the ears with a strap that goes over the head to keep them on]
sentence: Personal protective equipment such as hard hats and earmuffs also came into use.

translation: podsłuchiwać [to listen to someone's private conversation without them knowing]
sentence: He was eavesdropping on our conversation.

translation: żar, rozżarzony węgielek [a piece of wood or coal that is not burning but is still red and hot after a fire has died]
sentence: Only the embers of the bonfire remained.

translation: wyłaniać się [to appear by coming out of something or out from behind something; to become known, especially as a result of examining something or asking questions about it]
sentence: She emerged from the sea, blue with cold. No new evidence emerged during the investigation

translation: otaczać [to surround something, forming a circle around it]
sentence: The house is encircled by a high fence.

translation: konieczność, krytyczna sytuacja [formal; the difficulties of a situation, especially one that causes urgent demands]
sentence: Economic exigency obliged the government to act.

translation: fałsz [the state of not being true; the act of telling a lie]
sentence: She doesn't seem to understand the difference between truth and falsehood.

translation: opłata za przejazd, cena biletu [the money that you pay to travel by bus, plane, taxi, etc.]
sentence: When do the kids start paying the full fare?

translation: wierność [formal; honest or lasting support, or loyalty, especially to a sexual partner]
sentence: How important do you think sexual fidelity is in a marriage?

translation: wzdrygnąć się [to make a sudden, small movement because of pain or fear]
sentence: He didn't even flinch when the nurse cleaned the wound.

translation: przepowiadać, prorokować [to know or say what will happen in the future, especially by using magic powers]
sentence: He was a 16th-century prophet who foretold how the world would end.

translation: wesoło, radośnie [old-fashioned; in a bright and attractive way; in a cheerful way]
sentence: I could hear her gaily singing in her bedroom.

translation: skrzyć się, lśnić [to shine brightly with little flashes of light, like a diamond]
sentence: The ceiling of the cathedral glittered with gold.

translation: smakosz [a person who knows a lot about good food and wines and who enjoys choosing, eating, and drinking them]
sentence: She is a gourmet cook.

translation: biadolić [informal; to complain continuously about something in a way that is annoying]
sentence: There's no point griping about the price of things.

translation: gaj, lasek [a small group of trees; a small area of land with fruit trees of particular types on it]
sentence: Close to the mouth of the river was the sacred grove of the Italic goddess Marica.

translation: brudny, nieumyty [informal; fairly dirty, usually because it has not been washed or cleaned]
sentence: Don't wipe your grubby hands on my clean towel!

translation: tęsknić za, wzdychać za [to have a strong desire for something]
sentence: I’ve been hankering for a hot dog.

translation: wrzeszczeć [informal; to shout loudly]
sentence: He was hollering something about seeing a snake.

translation: bezbarwny, bez smaku, mdły [(disapproving) not having a strong taste or character, or having no interest or energy]
sentence: Why anyone buys music with such insipid lyrics is a mystery.

translation: przykry, nieprzyjemny [formal; annoying or irritating]
sentence: The vibration can become irksome after a while.

translation: pogodny, wesoły [marked by or suggestive of high spirits and lively mirthfulness]
sentence: Her jocund character made her the most popular girl in the county.

translation: plątanina [an untidy and confused mixture of things, feelings, or ideas]
sentence: The essay was a meaningless jumble of ideas.

translation: trawnik [an area of grass, especially near to a house or in a park, that is cut regularly to keep it short]
sentence: Will you mow the lawn at the weekend?

translation: wałęsać, kręcić się [to move slowly around or stand in a public place without an obvious reason]
sentence: A gang of youths were loitering outside the cinema.

translation: szpik kostny
sentence: Most patients die from bleeding or infection due to marrow failure.

translation: południk [an imaginary line between the North Pole and the South Pole, drawn on maps to help to show the position of a place]
sentence: The prime meridian of longitude is in Greenwich, London.

translation: myląca nazwa, błędna nazwa [a name that does not suit what it refers to, or the use of such a name]
sentence: It's something of a misnomer to refer to these inexperienced boys as soldiers.

translation: monsun [the season of heavy rain during the summer in hot Asian countries]
sentence: The failure of the monsoon would destroy harvests on which a billion people rely.

translation: powiedzieć bezgłośnie [to form words with the lips without making any sound]
sentence: It looks to me as if the singers are only mouthing the words.

translation: wymagać czegoś, zmuszać do czegoś [formal; to cause something to be needed, or to make something necessary]
sentence: Reduction in government spending will necessitate further cuts in public services.

translation: dolny [literary or humorous; in a lower position]
sentence: The boiler room is somewhere down in the building's nether regions.

translation: trujący, szkodliwy [formal; poisonous or harmful]
sentence: They died from inhaling noxious fumes.

translation: paczka [something that is covered in paper so that it can be sent by post]
sentence: The parcel was wrapped in plain brown paper.

translation: traktować protekcjonalnie [to treat someone in a way that seems friendly, but that shows that you think that they are not very intelligent, experienced, etc.]
sentence: Some television programs tend to patronize children.

translation: z konieczności [old-fashioned formal; because it is necessary or cannot be avoided]
sentence: They had perforce to abandon the attempt on the summit.

translation: nietrwały, łatwo psujący się [(especially of food) likely to decay or go bad quickly]
sentence: It's important to store perishable food in a cool place.

translation: gotować bez skorupki [to cook something such as a fish, or an egg with its shell removed, by putting it in gently boiling water or other liquid]
sentence: We had poached eggs for breakfast.

translation: por [a very small hole in the skin of people or other animals, or a similar hole on the surface of plants or rocks]
sentence: Sweat passes through the pores and cools the body down.

translation: urwisko, przepaść [a very steep side of a cliff or a mountain; a dangerous situation that could lead to harm or failure]
sentence: The film opens with a shot of a climber dangling from a precipice. This latest tax increase may push many small companies over the financial precipice.

translation: opory, skrupuły, wyrzuty sumienia [an uncomfortable feeling when you doubt if you are doing the right thing]
sentence: She had no qualms about lying to the police.

translation: zbierać plony, żąć [to cut and collect a grain crop; to obtain or receive something as a result of your own actions]
sentence: They didn’t reap any benefits from that deal.

translation: odwzajemniać [to behave or feel toward someone in the same way as they behave or feel toward you]
sentence: Her passion for him was not reciprocated.

translation: nawrót [formal; a sudden new appearance and growth, especially of something dangerous and unpleasant]
sentence: There has been an unwelcome recrudescence of racist attacks.

translation: niechętny [not willing to do something and therefore slow to do it]
sentence: I was having such a good time I was reluctant to leave.

translation: operacja plastyczna nosa [an operation to change the shape of the nose]
sentence: Rhinoplasty is a form of plastic surgery.

translation: rozdarty [literary; (of a group of people) divided because of disagreements, especially in a violent way; (of an object) divided into two or more pieces]
sentence: It was a community riven by hatred. The wood was riven with deep cracks.

translation: zmierzwić, wzburzyć [to disturb the smooth surface of something, so that it is not even; to make someone annoyed, worried, or upset]
sentence: She affectionately ruffled his hair with her hand as she passed.

translation: świętość [the state of being very important and worth protecting]
sentence: I believe in the sanctity of human life.

translation: woń, zapach [a pleasant natural smell]
sentence: The air was filled with the scent of wild flowers.

translation: przyprawiać [to add salt, pepper, etc. to food in order to give it more flavor]
sentence: Season the lamb with garlic.

translation: podły, podejrzany, obskurny [informal; looking dirty or in bad condition and likely to be involved in dishonest or illegal activities]
sentence: He didn't like the look of the seedy characters who were hanging around outside the bar.

translation: ząbkowany [having a row of sharp points along the edge]
sentence: You really need a knife with a serrated edge for cutting bread.

translation: powłóczyć nogami [to walk slowly and awkwardly, without lifting your feet correctly]
sentence: Sick patients shambled along the hospital corridors.

translation: smukły, szczupły [(approving) (of people or their bodies) thin in an attractive or elegant way]
sentence: He put his hands around her slender waist.

translation: drwić, szydzić [to show that you have no respect for someone by the expression on your face or by the way you speak]
sentence: You may sneer, but a lot of people like this kind of music.

translation: wieszcz, wróżbiarz [old use; a person who is believed to have the ability to know and tell what will happen in the future]
sentence: The soothsayers answered that it was an ill omen for it meant the destruction of the city and the death of many.

translation: splendor, wspaniałość [grand and impressive beauty; the beautiful and impressive features or qualities of something, especially a place]
sentence: They bought a decaying 16th-century manor house and restored it to its original splendor.

translation: gałązka [a small stem with leaves on it from a plant or bush, used in cooking or as a decoration]
sentence: Garnish the dish with sprigs of parsley.

translation: renoma, postura [formal; a person's height; the importance and respect that a person has because of their ability and achievements]
sentence: His stature as an art critic was tremendous.

translation: bocian
sentence: It reminded me of the fable of the stork inviting the fox to dinner.

translation: wywrotowy [formal; trying or likely to destroy or damage a government or political system by attacking it secretly or indirectly]
sentence: The FBI had the duty of obtaining evidence of subversive activity.

translation: gburowaty, opryskliwy [often in a bad mood, unfriendly, and not polite]
sentence: We were served by a very surly waiter.

translation: posmak, silny zapach [a strong, sharp taste or smell]
sentence: One has to say that this is due to the sharp tang of competition.

translation: charakterystyczny, zdradziecki, znamienny [showing something that someone is trying to keep secret; showing that something exists or has happened]
sentence: She was showing all the telltale signs of pregnancy. The telltale smell of cigarettes told her that he had been in the room.

translation: kwitnąć, prosperować [to grow, develop, or be successful]
sentence: His business thrived in the years before the war.

translation: cecha [a particular characteristic that can produce a particular type of behavior]
sentence: Arrogance is a very unattractive personality trait.

translation: okazać się, wyjść na jaw, następować [formal; to become known or apparent; to take place; to be revealed]
sentence: As it later transpired, she had known him at school.

translation: podejmować się [to do or begin to do something, especially something that will take a long time or be difficult]
sentence: Students are required to undertake simple experiments.

translation: znikać, przepadać [to disappear or stop being present or existing, especially in a sudden, surprising way]
sentence: The child vanished while on her way home from school.

translation: słabeusz [(disapproving) someone who is weak, either physically or in character]
sentence: It would need more than a few exercises to turn a seven-stone weakling into a heavyweight boxer.

translation: dobrze wyposażony [formal; having all the necessary equipment; having comfortable and attractive furniture, etc.]
sentence: The hotel has spacious, well-appointed public rooms and bedrooms.

translation: charczeć, sapać [to make a high, rough noise while breathing because of some breathing difficulty]
sentence: I know when I've been smoking too much because I start to wheeze when I run for a train.

translation: miażdżący [(of a look, remark, etc.) intended to make someone feel silly or ashamed]
sentence: He said that Lizzie had been drunk at the time and I saw her shoot him a withering glance.

translation: głupi, nieinteligentny [(disapproving) stupid or showing no intelligence]
sentence: In the book, Anna is forced to take care of her witless cousin.

translation: misternie wykonane [literary; made or done in a careful or decorative way]
sentence: The new album contains some carefully wrought new songs and a number of familiar hits.
